I've played around with the Tools Integration API and come up with:

http://www.geekfarm.org/emeade/junit/VajJunit.zip

Before anyone celebrates, there are some pretty big problems.  I'm 
rather disappointed.  Here is the readme:

-------------------
This is experimental software, use at your own risk, you have been 
warned.

Known Problems:

Classpath.  I haven't been able to figure out how to get the 
TestRunner to use the Vaj Classpath.  This means you have to export 
your tests into the junit directory under ide\tools.  It's a pain, 
I've experimented with Worspace.setClassPath, which has been 
resulting in a java.lang.InteralError when trying to load the test.

Default packages don't work well.  You can run the test, but double 
clicking on a failure won't open up the Class Browser.  the default 
package information needs to be saved before passed on to JUnit, and 
used again when opening the Class.  Shouldn't be that difficult to 
do, but in light of the other problem, it doesn't seem worth the 
effort.


Installation:

Shut down VisualAge for Java
Unzip VajJUnit.zip into your VisualAge for Java ide\tools directory.
Start VisualAge for Java.


Usage:

Export your test(s) to the ide/tools/junit directory.  (See Known 
Problem classpath)
Right click on the packages whose AllTests you want to run, or right 
click on the Test you want to run.
Select JUnit.
Select package or test run.
When a test fails and you double click on the TestFailure (not the 
stack trace, the failure) a Class browser for that test should be 
opened.  Can't take you to the exact line of the failure, don't see 
how it possible to do so.


Notes:

I modified JUnit slightly (hence the 3.5vaj version name), I changed 
the scope of junit.swingui.TestRunner.fTestRunViews from private to 
protected, so I could add a MouseListener to the JList which contains 
the failures.


Erik Meade
emeade@...
subject: Integration with VisualAge for Java
